messages.subject: Re: What the heck- someone is stealing my website?
messages.msgSnippet: Rich is right.  Clearly someone is taking your content as their own, and the only other section is a programmer s website design recommendations. I find
messages.messageBody:
Rich is right. Clearly someone is taking your content as their own,
and the only other section is a programmer's website design
recommendations.

I find content from my site popping up all over the internet. In
those few instances where I have asked the party to remove, or
otherwise cite satcho.com as the source, the request is often
ignored. Twice I have been told by (well known) sites owners' that a
third party who listed the stolen content did so without their
knowledge. Then in the most regulated of perfect worlds - the eBay
utopia with its guardians of what is fine, good, and proper, the
auction ends well before receiving a dismissive and self-serving,
automated reply from the eBay to my inquiry.

Ken - I enjoy your interesting - and novel - site documenting the
study of the mantis theme in tsuba, and hope that it continues
undeterred.



Michael Harris
satcho.com

http://www.satcho.com Specialists in books related to the study &
appreciation of the Japanese sword as art.

A sponsor of NihontoCalendar http://NihontoCalendar.org The portal
for Japanese sword collectors, dealers, museums, and galleries.

_______________________________________________

messages.subject: What the heck- someone is stealing my website?
messages.msgSnippet: I was searching and came across this site http://www.katchunk.com/fifty/sword/tsuba/mantis1.html . They are importing my mantis tsuba section  and building it
messages.messageBody:
I was searching and came across this site http://www.katchunk.com/fifty/sword/tsuba/mantis1.html . They are importing my mantis tsuba section and building it into their site. What the heck? It obviously is a work in progress but still what is going on here?
Ken
